awd_titl_txt: Phase I IUCRC Auburn University: Fiber-Wireless Integration and Networking (FiWIN) Center for Heterogeneous Mobile Data Communications
awd_abstract_narration:
The Fiber-Wireless Integration and Networking (FiWIN) Center for Heterogeneous Mobile Data Communications is an NSF Industry & University Cooperative Research Program (I/UCRC) center led by Georgia Institute of Technology (GIT). Based on recognized research leadership and accumulated expertise in integrated fiber-wireless access technologies, FiWIN is favorably positioned to explore emerging access network architectures, functional designs of network elements, and optimizing system interfaces and operations for next generation mobile communication systems. FiWIN has successfully completed two years in operation, while this project is to establish a new addition of Auburn University (AU) as a Member Site. 

The addition of AU broadens both technical expertise and, inevitably, new outcomes that can only be attributed to the "synergy" between GIT and AU. The FiWIN Center will continue to grow in visionary leadership, dedicated and well-rounded students, and the expanded interdisciplinary expertise. AU will contribute supplementary expertise focusing on: i) Radio Frequency Integrated Circuit (RFIC) design and future generation wireless systems, ii) innovative wireless applications such as unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV), and iii) the AU Radio-frequency identification (RFID) Laboratory will contribute to Internet of Things (IoT) research with applications to storage, retail, and supply chain management.

This project is part of a broad and ambitious collaborative effort between academia and industry to develop novel techniques to harvest the potential of heterogeneous mobile data communications enabled by the fifth generation wireless. It also strives to broaden participation from underrepresented groups. Graduate students will gain first-hand experience with industrial research projects. The outcomes from this project will be introduced into AU courses and an incoming textbook, and in particular, will enhance the Accreditation Board for Engineering and Technology (ABET) accredited Bachelor of Wireless Engineering (BWE) curriculum at Auburn University. Various venues will be explored for industrial collaborations. 

A reference library will be maintained and be accessible to center members. It will contain experimental data and research products, in addition to Center documents such as NSF Annual Reports, Level of Interest and Feedback Evaluation (LIFE) Form Reports, Center Publications, Industrial Advisory Board (IAB) Presentations and Posters, Membership Agreement document, By-Laws document, and Center Action Items. An interactive web-based server will be used for sharing scientific data produced from the project with the IAB and the public. A single Center-wide repository will be maintained for the center, at http://fiwin.org, which will be maintained throughout the project period.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The existing communication network infrastructure is experiencing fast growing pressures to accommodate much increased data throughput, while service providers seek to offer spectrally efficient, high bandwidth, large connectivity, low-latency and cost-effective broadband services over denser and wider areas of coverage. The scope of coordinated consortia and technology R&D activities in the US is lagging behind comparing with the research consortia in EU and East Asia. 

To date, FiWIN aims to be the focal point in the US dedicated to the development of novel 5G and beyond radio access networking technologies. FiWIN has pioneered millimeter wave (mmWave) radio over fiber (RoF) and digital signal processing technologies, and explored novel, all spectrum integration scenarios, and machine learning applications in emerging networks with optimized performance, promising innovations for 5G and beyond. While 5G is beginning its global roll-out, major R&D centers including FiWIN, are mapping out research challenges, assisted by early experience of 5G users, for essential ?post-5G? business and social applications. The FiWIN IUCRC is uniquely positioned from 5G outcomes to evolve into a partnership of universities and telecom stakeholders through pre-competitive, 6G technology vision and technical discoveries. The Auburn University (AU) site?s research has been focused on the two important themes of 5G and beyond: (i) key technological enablers of 5G and beyond and (ii) key applications that can fully harvest the new capability that is to be offered by 5G and beyond. The AU FiWIN team has developed a strong research program around the FiWIN themes. Results of the research have been disseminated among industrial members to foster the development of a competitive, widely available, high performance, and secure infrastructure for advanced, high performance mobile data communications.

FiWIN has orchestrated the seamless integration of technologies as varied as variants of machine learning, network management, resource distribution and control, signal processing and interference mitigation. The technologies developed from this project have provide a vital gateway for economic growth and societal media expansion with further scientific and engineering innovations. Development of innovative networking technologies and their dissemination have helped to spawn new markets to benefit US industrial offerings in 5G and beyond mobile data communications. Students have been trained in engineering, mathematics, AI & computer science. University curricula have also reflected advances learned in this project that stimulated great interest in science and technology among the broader community by engaging sponsored outreach opportunities offered by the existing programs at Georgia Tech and Auburn University.
